paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene mutation p.A97S in the context of familial amyloid polyneuropathy, providing details on penetrance, patient demographics, and functional data.

patients.demographics: Mean age 65.2±5.4 years, 14 male and 4 female
patients.phenotype: Patients with TTR-FAP presenting with rapidly progressive distally symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy

individual_records.phenotype_details: Rapidly progressive distally symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patients with TTR-FAP frequently present with a rapidly progressive distally symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Rapidly progressive distally symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patients with TTR-FAP frequently present with a rapidly progressive distally symmetric sensorimotor polyneuropathy.

functional_data.summary: Nerve excitability tests show increased thresholds and altered excitability indices in both patients and carriers.

variants.segregation_data: The p.A97S mutation segregates with disease in families.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the early involvement of both motor and sensory axons even in asymptomatic carriers.
key_quotes: The p.A97S mutation is the most common one among the patients in Taiwan.
The age of onset for patients with p.A97S TTR-FAP is usually in their seventh decade of life.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical demographic data for both patients and carriers

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper provided clear information on the TTR variant.
